docs.snippet: To the Editor:    When my daughter is instructed to use the Internet for a research paper, I fear that she will never experience the wonder I felt as a child upon entering the grand Brooklyn Central Library in search of information.    A Google se...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When my daughter is instructed to use the Internet for a research paper, I fear that she will never experience the wonder I felt as a child upon entering the grand Brooklyn Central Library in search of information. A Google search (''Behind the Rise of Google Lies the Rise in Internet Credibility,'' Editorial Observer, Feb. 27) cannot give her the smell and touch of an aging document, or the feeling of accomplishment after a hard day's work at the library.

headline.main: Around the (Virtual) World in Half a Second

docs.abstract: Sharon Aucoin letter on Verlyn Klinkenborg's Feb 27 column notes Internet searches involve exchange of speed and ease for richness of using library; drawing

docs.snippet: Yahoo said yesterday that it would start charging companies that want to ensure that their Web sites are included in its Web index from which research results are selected.       The practice, called ''paid inclusion,'' has long been a part of man...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo said yesterday that it would start charging companies that want to ensure that their Web sites are included in its Web index from which research results are selected. The practice, called ''paid inclusion,'' has long been a part of many search engines including Microsoft's MSN search function and Ask Jeeves. But Google, which last year surged ahead of Yahoo to become the No.1 site for searching on the Internet, disdains the practice as misleading.

headline.main: Yahoo to Charge for Guaranteeing a Spot on Its Index

docs.abstract: Yahoo will start charging companies that want to ensure that their Web sites are included in its Web index from which research results are selected; practice, called 'paid inclusion,' has long been part of many search engines; Google, which last year surged to become largest site for searching on Internet, disdains practice as misleading; sites will pay from $10 to $49 for each Web page indexed and from 15 cents to $1 each time Yahoo user clicks on link to their sites (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Behind the Rise of Google Lies the Rise in Internet Credibility,'' by Verlyn Klinkenborg (Editorial Observer, Feb. 27): I'm a novelist, a researcher, a nosy person and, of course, a plain old human being trying to live a complicated life.

headline.main: Around the (Virtual) World in Half a Second

docs.abstract: Kitty Burns Florey letter on Verlyn Klinkenborg's Feb 27 column cites ways in which Google has enlarged and enriched our lives, and made them easier; drawing

docs.snippet: Question: What makes 800 of the country's smartest, most wildly successful architects, designers, inventors, chief executives, psychologists, ichthyologists, cosmologists, economists, digital artists and other members of the creative, academic and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Question: What makes 800 of the country's smartest, most wildly successful architects, designers, inventors, chief executives, psychologists, ichthyologists, cosmologists, economists, digital artists and other members of the creative, academic and financial elite happy? Answer: Ruminating about ''The Pursuit of Happiness'' at the TED conference, the annual $4,000-a-pop three-and-a-half-day hedonistic be-in for the brain that brings together ''thought leaders'' from the worlds of technology, entertainment and design. Perhaps only at TED, as the 19-year-old conclave is known, would sexy Silicon Valley billionaires like Sergey Brin and Larry Page, the founders of Google, commune with nerdy M.I.T. professors who will attempt to explain string theory while hailing a taxicab.
docs.abstract: Annual TED conference in Monterey, Calif, brings together 'thought leaders' from worlds of technology, entertainment and design; photo; 19-year-old conclave was founded by information designer Richard Saul Wurman (M)
docs.section_name: Technology; Science; Home and Garden; Style

docs.snippet: BEN SILVERMAN is what you might call a Google obsessive. A producer and a former talent agent best known for bringing ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' to American television, Mr. Silverman Googles people he is lunching with. He Googles for breaki...
docs.lead_paragraph: BEN SILVERMAN is what you might call a Google obsessive. A producer and a former talent agent best known for bringing ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' to American television, Mr. Silverman Googles people he is lunching with. He Googles for breaking news, restaurant reviews and obscure song lyrics. He Googles prospective reality-show contestants to make sure they don't have naked pictures floating around the Web. And, like every self-respecting Hollywood player, he Googles himself. Competitively. ''Guys all over town are on the phone saying, 'I bet I can get more Google hits than you.' '' he said recently. ''It's become this ridiculous new power game.''

docs.snippet: A FEW more ways to search away the hours:    GOOGLE DICTIONARY -- Enter ''define'' at Google's search box, a space and the expression you want defined.    GOOGLISM -- What Google thinks of you. www.googlism.com....
docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW more ways to search away the hours: GOOGLE DICTIONARY -- Enter ''define'' at Google's search box, a space and the expression you want defined. GOOGLISM -- What Google thinks of you. www.googlism.com.

docs.snippet: An article last Sunday about the popularity of the Internet search engine Google and its effect on the broader culture referred imprecisely to the founding of Google Inc. by two Stanford University doctoral students, Sergey Brin and Larry Page. Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the popularity of the Internet search engine Google and its effect on the broader culture referred imprecisely to the founding of Google Inc. by two Stanford University doctoral students, Sergey Brin and Larry Page. The two began collaborating on a search engine in 1995 and eventually set up a data center in a Stanford dormitory; when the company was officially founded in 1998, it opened in an office in a garage. (It was not founded in the dorm in that year and subsequently moved to the garage.) The article also misstated the title of Susan Wojcicki. She is Google's director of product management, not product placement.
docs.abstract: Corrections of Mar 14 article on Google: Sergey Brin and Larry Page began collaborating on search engine in 1995 at Stanford University; officially founded company in 1998 in garage office; Susan Wojcicki is Google's director of product management, not product placement

docs.snippet: IF we lived in Afghanistan under the Taliban, perhaps it might make sense that Janet Jackson's breast (not even the matched set!) would lead to one of the most hysterical outbreaks of Puritanism in recent, even not-so-recent, American history. So ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF we lived in Afghanistan under the Taliban, perhaps it might make sense that Janet Jackson's breast (not even the matched set!) would lead to one of the most hysterical outbreaks of Puritanism in recent, even not-so-recent, American history. So what gives? In the seven weeks since Super Bowl Sunday, the radio jock Howard Stern, under fire for the same old salacious shtick he's mined for more than two decades, has taken on the free-speech martyrdom mantle of Lenny Bruce. Sandra Tsing Loh, a longtime commentator on the public radio station KCRW-FM in Los Angeles, has been fired because her engineer failed to bleep an expletive in a prerecorded commentary. Congress has concocted a Clean Airways Act that is itself a self-parodying bureaucratic concordance of foul language, complete with references to ''hyphenated compounds'' and ''infinitive forms.'' (Google ''H.R. 3687,'' and you'll find the scatological mother lode, rounded up at taxpayers' expense.)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I very much enjoyed reading your review of ''The Birth of Venus,'' by Sarah Dunant (March 7). As an artist who has devoted her life to silverpoint drawing, however, I feel compelled to correct any misimpression caused by the phra...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed reading your review of ''The Birth of Venus,'' by Sarah Dunant (March 7). As an artist who has devoted her life to silverpoint drawing, however, I feel compelled to correct any misimpression caused by the phrase ''silverpoint engravings.'' Engraving is a common printmaking technique for making multiple copies. Silverpoint is a drawing tool for unique works of art that was popular in the Renaissance but then eventually supplanted by pencil and chalk. The artist uses a sterling silver stylus on a prepared surface to make a mark. If your readers type in the words ''silverpoint drawing'' on Google, they will find many beautiful examples of Renaissance silverpoint drawings as well as contemporary images. Susan Schwalb New York
docs.abstract: Susan Schwalb letter on Valerie Martin March 7 review of The Birth of Venus by Sarah Dunant (S)
